member.name: T:DigitalRune.Graphics.Content.Pipeline.AnimationSplitter
member.summary: Splits an animation into separate animations based on an XML file defining the splits.

remarks.para: Some FBX exporters support only a single animation (take) per model. One solution to support multiple animations per model is to concatenate all animations into a single long one. A separate, manually created XML file defines the animation sections.
remarks.example:
The XML file allows to specify the start and end times in "seconds" or in "frames". The file must use this format:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?> <Animations Framerate="24"> <!-- Framerate only needed if you want to specify start and end in frames. --> <!-- Using time in seconds: --> <Animation Name="Walk" StartTime="0" EndTime="1.5"/>
<!-- Or using frames: --> <Animation Name="Walk2" StartFrame="45" EndFrame="60"/> </Animations>
remarks.para: The method parses the XML split definition file, removes the original animation and cuts it into separate animations.

member.name: M:DigitalRune.Graphics.Content.Pipeline.AnimationSplitter.Split(Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Content.Pipeline.Graphics.AnimationContentDictionary,System.String,Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Content.Pipeline.ContentIdentity,Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Content.Pipeline.ContentProcessorContext)

overloads.summary: Splits the animation in the specified animation dictionary into several separate animations.

member.summary: Splits the animation in the specified animation dictionary into several separate animations.
member.param: The path of the XML file defining the splits. This path is relative to the folder of the model file. Usually it is simply the filename, e.g. "Dude_AnimationSplits.xml".

member.summary: Splits the animation in the specified animation dictionary into several separate animations.

member.summary: Parses the animation split definitions defined by the specified XML element.
member.param: The XML element that defines the animation splits.
member.returns: The list of animation split definitions.

member.name: T:DigitalRune.Graphics.Content.Pipeline.DRTextureFormat
member.summary: Defines the texture format.

member.name: F:DigitalRune.Graphics.Content.Pipeline.DRTextureFormat.NoChange
member.summary: The texture format of the input texture is not changed by the content processor.

member.name: F:DigitalRune.Graphics.Content.Pipeline.DRTextureFormat.Color
member.summary: The texture format of the input texture is converted to SurfaceFormat.Color (32-bit ARGB format with alpha, 8 bits per channel) by the content processor.

member.name: F:DigitalRune.Graphics.Content.Pipeline.DRTextureFormat.Dxt
member.summary: The texture format of the input texture is converted to an appropriate DXT compression by the content processor. (If the input texture contains fractional alpha values, it is converted to DXT5 format; otherwise it is converted to DXT1.)

member.name: F:DigitalRune.Graphics.Content.Pipeline.DRTextureFormat.Normal
member.summary: The texture format of the input texture is converted to DXT5nm by the content processor. (This format reduces compression artifacts when storing normal maps. The x-component of the normal is stored in the Alpha channel and the y-component is stored in the Green channel. The z-component needs to be reconstructed in the pixel shader.)

member.name: F:DigitalRune.Graphics.Content.Pipeline.DRTextureFormat.NormalInvertY
member.summary: The texture format of the input texture is converted to DXT5nm by the content processor. (This format reduces compression artifacts when storing normal maps. The x-component of the normal is stored in the Alpha channel and the inverted y-component is stored in the Green channel. The z-component needs to be reconstructed in the pixel shader.)

member.name: T:DigitalRune.Graphics.Content.MeshValidationOptions
member.summary: Defines options for mesh validation.

member.name: F:DigitalRune.Graphics.Content.MeshValidationOptions.Default
member.summary: Check for most basic problems such as invalid index entries. If adjacency information is provided, then that list is also validated.

member.name: F:DigitalRune.Graphics.Content.MeshValidationOptions.Backfacing
member.summary: Check for duplicate neighbors which usually indicate inconsistent winding order. This requires adjacency information.

member.name: F:DigitalRune.Graphics.Content.MeshValidationOptions.Bowties
member.summary: Check for two fans of triangles that use the same vertex, but are not adjacent. This requires adjacency information.

member.name: F:DigitalRune.Graphics.Content.MeshValidationOptions.Degenerate
member.summary: Check for degenerate triangles.

member.name: F:DigitalRune.Graphics.Content.MeshValidationOptions.Unused
member.summary: Check for issues with 'unused' triangles such as partial 'unused' faces. If adjacency is provided, it also validates that 'unused' faces are not neighbors of other faces.

member.name: F:DigitalRune.Graphics.Content.MeshValidationOptions.AsymmetricAdjacency
member.summary: Check that every neighbor face links back to the original face. This requires adjacency.

member.name: T:DigitalRune.Graphics.Content.DirectXMesh
member.summary: Provides various geometry processing functions.

remarks.para: DirectXMesh. Copyright (c) 2015 Microsoft Corp. Available under MIT license.
This is a port of the D3DX geometry processing functions.

Normals, tangents, and bi-tangents:
Geometric meshes often must include surface information for lighting computations.

A normal is defined as surface normal perpendicular to the mesh. Triangular meshes imply a face normal defined by the winding order of the vertices of the triangles (typically counter-clockwise, although clockwise winding can also be used). For efficient rendering, vertex normals are used for rendering rather than face normals.

A tangent and a bi-tangent are gradient direction vectors along the surface of a mesh. Together with the normal they describe a full 3-axis coordinate system useful for many advanced lighting techniques.
See: ,

Adjacency computation:
A useful property of geometric meshes is the adjacency relationship between faces of the mesh as defined by sharing triangle edges.

The adjacency is represented as an array of index values with 3 entries for each triangular face in the mesh. Each entry is the face index of the triangular face that is adjacent to one edge of the triangular face (hence as there are three edges, there can be up to 3 triangular faces that share an edge). If there is no adjacent face, the index is set to -1.

The point representative (aka point rep) is an array of index values with one entry for each vertex in the mesh. Each entry is the vertex index of a vertex with a unique position. If there are no vertices that share the same location, each entry of the pointRep array is the identity (i.e. pointRep[i] == i). If there are duplicated vertex positions in the mesh, then some entry will point to another 'representative' vertex index.
See: , ,

Cleanup and validation:
Triangular mesh descriptions can contain a number of errors which result in invalid or failed geometric operations. There are also a number of cases where a triangular mesh description can cause mesh algorithms to fail. These functions can detect and resolve such issues.
See: ,

Mesh optimization:
Direct3D can render valid meshes with the same visual results no matter how the data is ordered, but the efficiency of the rendering performance can be impacted by ordering that is well-matched to modern GPUs. Mesh optimization is a process for reordering faces and vertices to provide the same visual result, with improved utilization of hardware resources.
See: , , ,
A complete mesh optimization includes

member.name: M:DigitalRune.Graphics.Content.DirectXMesh.OptimizeFaces(System.Collections.Generic.IList{System.Int32},System.Collections.Generic.IList{System.Int32},System.Collections.Generic.IList{System.Int32},System.Int32[]@,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Reorders faces to improve post-transform vertex cache reuse.
member.param: A 32-bit indexed description of the triangles in a mesh. This must have 3 * numberOfFaces entries, and every group of 3 describes the vertices for a triangle face. This is the index buffer data suited for use with D3D11_PRIMITIVE_TOPOLOGY_TRIANGLELIST. An entry of -1 is reserved as 'unused' (Direct3D 11 interprets this special value as a strip restart). Any face containing one or more -1 entries is considered an 'unused' face.
A 32-bit index array with numberOfFaces * 3 entries containing the edge adjacencies for each face in a mesh. Can be -1 to indicate an unused entry.
A 32-bit index array with numberOfFaces entries which contains the attribute id for each face in the mesh. Can be .
The array describing the reordering. See and for details.

The size of the vertex cache to assume for the optimization. If is provided, then the vertex cache simulation is not used and the faces are put in "strip order". This number should typically range from 0 to 32. The default value is .
The threshold used to control when strips are restarted based. This number must be less than or equal to , and is ignored . The default value is .

remarks.para: This implements the same algorithm as D3DX with explicit control over the simulated vertex cache size. OPTFACES_V_DEFAULT / OPTFACES_R_DEFAULT is the same value that D3DXOptimizeFaces used (i.e. D3DXMESHOPT_DEVICEINDEPENDENT).
Some vendors support a Direct3D 9 query D3DQUERYTYPE_VCACHE that reports the vertex cache optimization settings that are device specific.

Note that optimizing for a larger than is present on the hardware can result in poorer performance than the original mesh, so this value should be picked either for a known fixed device or conservatively.
Degenerate and 'unused' faces are skipped by the optimization, so they do not appear in the remap order.

member.exception:
The number of indices is 0 or not a multiple of 3.
Or, a validation option is specified that requires which is missing.
Or, the length of does not match .

overloads.summary: Reorders a 32-bit index buffer based on a face remap array.

member.summary: Reorders a 32-bit index buffer based on a face remap array.
member.param: An array with one entry per face that describes how to reorder the faces of the original mesh. For each face in the optimized mesh, it provides the original location of that face. See and .
member.remarks:
This is the pseudo-code of how to apply a face remap.
for each j in nFaces origFace = faceRemap[ j ] if ( origFace != -1 ) for each i in 0..2 newIndices[ j*3 + i ] = indices[ origFace*3 + i ]
member.exception:
The number of indices is 0 or not a multiple of 3.
The length of does not match the number of faces.

member.name: M:DigitalRune.Graphics.Content.DirectXMesh.FinalizeVB(System.Byte[],System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32[],System.Int32[],System.Byte[]@)

overloads.summary: Finishes mesh optimization by reordering vertices and/or adding duplicated vertices for the vertex buffer.

member.summary: Finishes mesh optimization by reordering vertices and/or adding duplicated vertices for the vertex buffer.
member.param: The vertex stride (= size of a vertex) in bytes.
The number of vertices in the mesh.

An array containing an entry for each vertex that needs duplicating. Each entry indicates the index of the original vertex buffer to duplicate. The array also indicates reorder information for the duplicated vertices.
An array with one entry per vertex that describes how to reorder the vertices of the original mesh. This maps the original vertex location to the optimized location. See .

remarks.para: This is the pseudo-code for applying a vertex remap to a vertex buffer:
remarks.code:
for each j in nVerts newIndex = vertexRemap[j] if (newIndex != -1) memcpy(newVB + newIndex * stride, oldVB + j * stride, stride)
for each j in nDupVerts newIndex = vertexRemap[j + nVerts] if (newIndex != -1) memcpy(newVB + newIndex * stride, oldVB + dup[j] * stride, stride)

member.name: M:DigitalRune.Graphics.Content.DirectXMesh.ComputeVertexCacheMissRate(System.Collections.Generic.IList{System.Int32},System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Single@,System.Single@)
member.summary: Calculates the average cache miss ratio (ACMR) and average triangle vertex re-use (ATVR) for the post-transform vertex cache.
member.param: A 32-bit indexed description of the triangles in a mesh. This must have 3 * numberOfFaces entries, and every group of 3 describes the vertices for a triangle face. This is the index buffer data suited for use with D3D11_PRIMITIVE_TOPOLOGY_TRIANGLELIST. An entry of -1 is reserved as 'unused' (Direct3D 11 interprets this special value as a strip restart). Any face containing one or more -1 entries is considered an 'unused' face.
The number of vertices in the mesh.
The size of the cache. Pass OPTFACES_V_DEFAULT as the cache size to evaluate the 'device independent' optimization.
member.exception: The number of indices is 0 or not a multiple of 3.

member.summary: Additional options for .

member.name: F:DigitalRune.Graphics.Content.DdsFlags.None
member.summary: None.

member.name: F:DigitalRune.Graphics.Content.DdsFlags.LegacyDword
member.summary: Assume pitch is DWORD aligned instead of BYTE aligned (used by some legacy DDS files).

member.name: F:DigitalRune.Graphics.Content.DdsFlags.NoLegacyExpansion
member.summary: Do not implicitly convert legacy formats that result in larger pixel sizes (24 bpp, 3:3:2, A8L8, A4L4, P8, A8P8).

member.name: F:DigitalRune.Graphics.Content.DdsFlags.NoR10B10G10A2Fixup
member.summary: Do not use work-around for long-standing D3DX DDS file format issue which reversed the 10:10:10:2 color order masks.

member.name: F:DigitalRune.Graphics.Content.DdsFlags.ForceRgb
member.summary: Convert DXGI 1.1 BGR formats to R8G8B8A8_UNORM to avoid use of optional WDDM 1.1 formats.

member.name: F:DigitalRune.Graphics.Content.DdsFlags.No16Bpp
member.summary: Conversions avoid use of 565, 5551, and 4444 formats and instead expand to 8888 to avoid use of optional WDDM 1.2 formats.

member.name: F:DigitalRune.Graphics.Content.DdsFlags.ExpandLuminance
member.summary: When loading legacy luminance formats expand replicating the color channels rather than leaving them packed (L8, L16, A8L8).

member.name: F:DigitalRune.Graphics.Content.DdsFlags.ForceDX10Ext
member.summary: Always use the 'DX10' header extension for DDS writer (i.e. don't try to write DX9 compatible DDS files).

member.name: F:DigitalRune.Graphics.Content.DdsFlags.ForceDX10ExtMisc2
member.summary: DDS_FLAGS_FORCE_DX10_EXT including miscFlags2 information (result may not be compatible with D3DX10 or D3DX11).

member.name: T:DigitalRune.Graphics.Content.Texture
member.summary: Represents a texture resource. (For use in content pipeline. Not intended to be used at runtime.)

remarks.para: The can represent 1D, 2D, 3D (volume) textures, cube maps, and texture arrays. The implementation is API-independent and is used for processing assets in the content pipeline.
A texture consists of one or more images (see ). The order of the images is the same as Direct3D uses for texture subresources. Use to find the index of a specific image.

member.name: M:DigitalRune.Graphics.Content.TextureHelper.IsPacked(DigitalRune.Graphics.Content.DataFormat)
member.summary: Determines whether the specified texture format is a packed format.
member.remarks: YUV formats are divided into packed formats and planar formats. In a packed format, the Y, U, and V components are stored in a single array. Pixels are organized into groups of macropixels, whose layout depends on the format. In a planar format, the Y, U, and V components are stored as three separate planes. (Source: Recommended 8-Bit YUV Formats for Video Rendering)

member.name: M:DigitalRune.Graphics.Content.TextureHelper.IsPlanar(DigitalRune.Graphics.Content.DataFormat)
member.summary: Determines whether the specified texture format is a planar format.
member.remarks: YUV formats are divided into packed formats and planar formats. In a packed format, the Y, U, and V components are stored in a single array. Pixels are organized into groups of macropixels, whose layout depends on the format. In a planar format, the Y, U, and V components are stored as three separate planes. (Source: Recommended 8-Bit YUV Formats for Video Rendering)

member.name: M:DigitalRune.Graphics.Content.Squish.CompressMasked(System.Byte*,System.Int32,System.Byte*,DigitalRune.Graphics.Content.SquishFlags,System.Nullable{DigitalRune.Mathematics.Algebra.Vector3F},DigitalRune.Graphics.Content.Squish.Context)
member.summary: Compresses a 4x4 block of pixels.
member.param: The rgba values of the 16 source pixels.
Storage for the compressed DXT block.

remarks.para: The source pixels should be presented as a contiguous array of 16 rgba values, with each component as 1 byte each. In memory this should be:

The mask parameter enables only certain pixels within the block. The lowest bit enables the first pixel and so on up to the 16th bit. Bits beyond the 16th bit are ignored. Pixels that are not enabled are allowed to take arbitrary colours in the output block. An example of how this can be used is in the CompressImage function to disable pixels outside the bounds of the image when the width or height is not divisible by 4.

The flags parameter should specify either , or compression, however, DXT1 will be used by default if none is specified. When using DXT1 compression, 8 bytes of storage are required for the compressed DXT block. DXT3 and DXT5 compression require 16 bytes of storage per block.

The flags parameter can also specify a preferred colour compressor to use when fitting the RGB components of the data. Possible colour compressors are: (the default), (very fast, low quality) or (slowest, best quality).

When using or , an additional flag can be specified to weight the importance of each pixel by its alpha value. For images that are rendered using alpha blending, this can significantly increase the perceived quality.

can be used to weight the relative importance of each colour channel, or pass to use the default uniform weight of (1.0, 1.0, 1.0). This replaces the previous flag-based control that allowed either uniform or "perceptual" weights with the fixed values (0.2126, 0.7152, 0.0722).

member.name: M:DigitalRune.Graphics.Content.Squish.Decompress(System.Byte*,System.Byte*,DigitalRune.Graphics.Content.SquishFlags)
member.summary: Compresses a 4x4 block of pixels.
member.param: Storage for the compressed DXT block.
The rgba values of the 16 source pixels.

remarks.para: The decompressed pixels will be written as a contiguous array of 16 rgba values, with each component as 1 byte each. In memory this is:
The flags parameter should specify either kDxt1, kDxt3 or kDxt5 compression, however, DXT1 will be used by default if none is specified. All other flags are ignored.

member.name: M:DigitalRune.Graphics.Content.Squish.GetStorageRequirements(System.Int32,System.Int32,DigitalRune.Graphics.Content.SquishFlags)
member.summary: Computes the amount of compressed storage required.
member.returns: The memory (in bytes) required to store the compressed image.

remarks.para: The flags parameter should specify either , or compression, however, DXT1 will be used by default if none is specified. All other flags are ignored.
Most DXT images will be a multiple of 4 in each dimension, but this function supports arbitrary size images by allowing the outer blocks to be only partially used.

member.summary: Compresses an image in memory.
member.param: The width of the source image.
The height of the source image.

remarks.para: The source pixels should be presented as a contiguous array of 16 rgba values, with each component as 1 byte each. In memory this should be:

The flags parameter should specify either , or compression, however, DXT1 will be used by default if none is specified. When using DXT1 compression, 8 bytes of storage are required for the compressed DXT block. DXT3 and DXT5 compression require 16 bytes of storage per block.

The flags parameter can also specify a preferred colour compressor to use when fitting the RGB components of the data. Possible colour compressors are: (the default), (very fast, low quality) or (slowest, best quality).

When using or , an additional flag can be specified to weight the importance of each pixel by its alpha value. For images that are rendered using alpha blending, this can significantly increase the perceived quality.

can be used to weight the relative importance of each colour channel, or pass to use the default uniform weight of (1.0, 1.0, 1.0). This replaces the previous flag-based control that allowed either uniform or "perceptual" weights with the fixed values (0.2126, 0.7152, 0.0722).

Internally this function calls for each block, which allows for pixels outside the image to take arbitrary values. The function can be called to compute the amount of memory to allocate for the compressed output.

member.summary: Decompresses an image in memory.

The height of the source image.

remarks.para: The decompressed pixels will be written as a contiguous array of * rgba values, with each component as 1 byte each. In memory this is:
{ r1, g1, b1, a1, .... , rn, gn, bn, an } for n = width * height
The flags parameter should specify either , or compression, however, DXT1 will be used by default if none is specified. All other flags are ignored.
